Australia:
The transportation of convicts to Norfolk Island ceased.
All men over 21 years of age obtained the right to vote in South Australia.
Belgium: Pierre de Decker replaces Henri de Brouckère as Prime Minister
China: Third plague pandemic: A plague pandemic began in Yunnan which would kill hundreds of thousands in China and millions worldwide. Punti-Hakka Clan Wars: An ethnic conflict began in Guangdong between the Punti and Hakka peoples which would claim roughly a million lives.
India:
Rani Rashmoni builds the Dakshineswar Kali Temple.
Santhal rebellion
Japan:
The Treaty of Shimoda with the Russian Empire was signed.
With the arrival of the modern Dutch paddle steamer Kankō Maru, the Tokugawa shogunate establishes the Nagasaki Naval Training Center as part of its modernization efforts to meet the perceived military threat posed by the western nations and learn Western-style science and naval theory. The cadets who attended the center such as Enomoto Takeaki and Katsu Kaishū would go on to found the Imperial Japanese Navy following the Meiji Restoration in 1868.
The Ansei great earthquakes series ends with the 1855 Edo earthquake followed by a devastating fire.
Malta: Three Gozitan representatives personally petition Pope Pius IX for a separate Roman Catholic diocese for Gozo; the pontiff promises his support.
Mexico:
• The Reform laws begin, separating the Catholic Church and the government of Mexico. Principal leaders were Juan Álvarez, Ignacio Comonfort, Benito Juárez, and Sebastián Lerdo de Tejada.
  • Juan Álvarez takes office as Interim President of Mexico in Cuernavaca.
Russia: Nicholas died. His son, Alexander II, became tsar.
Singapore: Edmund Augustus Blundell was appointed as the Governor of the Straits Settlements upon the retirement of William John Butterworth.
Sweden: Construction begins on Sweden's first railway line
